chapters.title: A Bittersweet Bequest
chapters.summary: Harried city archivist Eleanor Vance arrives in Honeywick to settle her eccentric Aunt Agatha's estate, expecting only a brief, sentimental trip.
key_events: Eleanor receives the news of her aunt's peaceful passing.
She arrives at the overgrown, charming cottage 'Marmalade Nook'.
Meets the nosy but friendly chair of the village fête committee, Mrs. Plum.
Discovers the vast collection of vintage cookbooks, organized with librarian precision.
The solicitor emphasizes Agatha's specific wish for Eleanor to 'care for the collection.'
chapters.ending_hook: As Eleanor pulls a dusty, orange-spattered cookbook titled 'Preserves of the British Isles' from a shelf, a brittle, handwritten note flutters to the floor, its first line reading: 'They think it was an accident, but the river doesn't lie...'

chapters.title: Stains and Suspicions
chapters.summary: Eleanor examines the curious note and the cookbook it came from, finding more cryptic annotations that suggest a hidden purpose.
key_events: The note is tucked into a recipe for Seville Orange Marmalade.
Eleanor finds more pages with tiny, coded markings in the margins—dates, initials, and symbols.
She learns from a villager that Agatha was known for her award-winning marmalade.
A local postman mentions Agatha's 'quiet curiosity' about village history.
Eleanor finds a locked, empty journal in the desk, labeled 'The Honeywick Matter.'
chapters.ending_hook: Holding the note up to the light, Eleanor sees faint impressions on the paper—not from writing, but from a newspaper clipping that once lay beneath it, featuring a headline about a missing local girl from 1956.

chapters.title: The Girl from the Gazette
chapters.summary: Eleanor visits the local archive and discovers the true story of Lily Bright, a vivacious teenager who vanished without a trace in 1956.
key_events: Eleanor finds the original clipping about Lily Bright's disappearance.
The official story was that she ran away to London, but the case went cold.
She learns Lily worked part-time at the now-closed village sweet shop.
Agatha, then a young librarian, had compiled a discreet file of newspaper snippets.
Eleanor realizes the dates in the cookbook notes correspond to the weeks after Lily vanished.
chapters.ending_hook: In Agatha's file, Eleanor finds a photo of Lily with three friends at the village fair—one face is neatly cut out of the picture with scissors.

chapters.title: A Recipe for Riddles
chapters.summary: Eleanor begins to systematically decode her aunt's culinary cipher, realizing each recipe holds a piece of the investigation.
key_events: Eleanor deduces that recipe ingredients correspond to people (e.g., 'bitter almonds' for a suspicious person).
Cooking instructions seem to describe actions or meetings.
She identifies the initials of Lily's three friends from the photo.
One friend, 'T.S.', is now the gruff local butcher, Thomas Sewell.
Mrs. Plum casually mentions that Thomas and Lily were 'sweethearts, for a time.'
chapters.ending_hook: The final line of the coded marmalade recipe reads: 'For truth to set, it must be poured while hot. Find the jar in the usual place.'

chapters.title: The Usual Place
chapters.summary: Interpreting the clue, Eleanor searches Agatha's usual hiding spots and finds a physical piece of evidence.
key_events: Eleanor checks Agatha's pantry, potting shed, and the hollow of an old apple tree.
In a disused beehive at the bottom of the garden, she finds a sealed mason jar.
Inside is not marmalade, but a delicate pearl hair clip, wrapped in wax paper.
A tiny, tarnished engraving on the clip reads 'L.B.'
Mrs. Plum identifies it instantly: 'Oh, that was Lily's. She wore it every day.'
chapters.ending_hook: As Eleanor holds the hair clip, she sees Thomas the butcher watching her from the lane, his expression unreadable before he turns and walks quickly away.

chapters.title: Sweet Talk and Sour Notes
chapters.summary: Eleanor begins tentative inquiries, interviewing Lily's old friends under the guise of researching village history for her aunt's collection.
key_events: She interviews the second friend, Betty, now a nervous florist who claims to remember little.
The third friend, Robert, left the village years ago for Australia.
Thomas the butcher is hostile and dismissive, telling her to 'let sleeping dogs lie.'
The elderly postman recalls Lily had a 'secret admirer' who left notes in the shop till.
Eleanor finds a coded note in a scone recipe suggesting Agatha suspected a 'wolf in shepherd's clothing.'
chapters.ending_hook: Returning to the cottage, Eleanor finds the back door slightly ajar and all her aunt's cookbooks pulled from the shelves and scattered across the floor.

chapters.title: A Tangled Web
chapters.summary: After the break-in, Eleanor is shaken but more determined. She uncovers a connection to a respected village figure.
key_events: Nothing is stolen, but the cookbooks are in disarray—someone was looking for something.
Constable Wells files a report but suggests it was likely kids.
Eleanor discovers a new set of initials in a jam recipe: 'V.V.'
Research reveals 'V.V.' was the vicar in 1956, Reverend Vernon Croft.
Mrs. Plum mentions, offhandedly, that the Reverend was a 'great comfort' to Lily's family after she vanished.
chapters.ending_hook: In the churchyard, Eleanor finds Reverend Croft's gravestone. The date of his death is exactly one week after Agatha's first coded note in the marmalade book.

chapters.title: Burying the Past
chapters.summary: Eleanor digs into the Reverend's history and finds a discrepancy in his saintly reputation.
key_events: The church archives show Reverend Croft organized youth outings.
An elderly chorister mentions the Reverend had a 'temper' and a 'fixation on purity.'
Eleanor finds a coded note in a gingerbread recipe about a 'sweetness used to lure.'
She learns Lily was seen arguing with a tall man in a long coat near the river the night she disappeared.
The description of the coat matches the Reverend's ceremonial cassock.
chapters.ending_hook: Searching the riverbank described in the first note, Eleanor's foot sinks into the mud and dislodges a small, tarnished silver cross on a broken chain—the kind worn by a clergyman.

chapters.title: The Wolf Revealed
chapters.summary: Eleanor pieces together Agatha's theory: the Reverend, the 'wolf in shepherd's clothing,' was Lily's secret admirer and likely responsible for her disappearance.
key_events: The coded notes now form a coherent narrative of Agatha's suspicion.
She believed Lily threatened to expose the Reverend's inappropriate advances.
A 'simmering' note suggests a confrontation by the river.
Agatha's theory was that the 'accidental drowning' was staged.
Eleanor realizes the cookbooks were scattered because someone is looking for Agatha's evidence, fearing she wrote it all down.
chapters.ending_hook: Thomas the butcher arrives at her door, not with hostility, but with a pale face and a confession: 'I saw them by the river that night. I've been afraid for fifty years.'

chapters.title: A Conscience Unburdened
chapters.summary: Thomas reveals what he witnessed, confirming Agatha's suspicions and providing a crucial missing piece.
key_events: As a teen, Thomas followed Lily and saw her meet Reverend Croft.
He witnessed a violent struggle; Lily fell and hit her head on a rock.
Terrified, he ran away and never told anyone.
The Reverend reported her missing the next day, suggesting she'd run away.
Thomas admits he has been watching Eleanor, afraid the truth would come out, and that he was the one who ransacked the cottage looking for Agatha's notes.
chapters.ending_hook: Just as Thomas finishes his story, Constable Wells knocks on the door, having been anonymously tipped off about 'harassment' of elderly villagers by the city niece.

chapters.title: The Last Jar
chapters.summary: With the Constable skeptical and the village whispering, Eleanor must find Agatha's final, conclusive piece of evidence to prove the theory.
key_events: Eleanor is cautioned by Constable Wells to drop her 'fantasies.'
She re-examines the cookbooks and finds one last clue in a recipe for 'Blackberry & Apple Silence.'
The clue points to the church vestry, to a specific hymnal.
With Mrs. Plum as a lookout, Eleanor searches the vestry.

Tucked behind the hymnal is Agatha's final document: a signed, witnessed statement from 1957, detailing her suspicions and the fact she'd found the pearl hair clip by the river, withheld from the police to continue her investigation.
chapters.ending_hook: As Eleanor holds the statement, the vestry door creaks open, and the current vicar—Reverend Croft's grandson—stands there, having heard everything.

chapters.title: Setting the Truth
chapters.summary: The truth is finally brought to light, the village reconciles with its past, and Eleanor finds a new purpose.
key_events: The vicar, though shocked, agrees the statement must go to the proper authorities.
Constable Wells, presented with the evidence, reopens the cold case.
Lily Bright's remaining family is given closure, though no one living can be prosecuted.
Eleanor decides to keep Marmalade Nook, using it as a writing retreat.
She and Mrs. Plum organize a memorial for both Lily and Agatha, celebrating their lives.
chapters.ending_hook: At the village fête, Eleanor enters a jar of marmalade made from Agatha's recipe. As she spreads it on a scone, she notices a new, friendly note from Mrs. Plum tucked into the recipe book—the first page of a brand new, and much happier, village mystery.
